title: Energy Department to Ban Foreign Talent-Recruitment Programs
summary: U.S. takes aim at programs run by China and others it says can threaten national security. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Energy Department says it will ban its scientists and other employees from participating in talent-recruitment programs sponsored by China and other countries suspected of using them to obtain sensitive research.

title: Marie Kondo Says You Can Have More Than 30 Books, Just Wake Them Up First
summary: 'What is most important is whether they spark joy and knowing what makes you feel most comfortable'. Don't worry, book lovers. It's fine with Marie Kondo if your bookshelf has more than 30 volumes.

title: Big Oil Companies Finished 2018 Strong Despite Plunge in Oil Prices
summary: Exxon, Chevron posted solid fourth-quarter earnings, following similar results from Shell. HOUSTON-The world's largest Western oil companies shrugged off a 38% plunge in oil prices during the final months of 2018 to post some of their biggest annual profits in years.

title: Spotify in Talks to Buy Gimlet Media
summary: Deal for podcasting group would help Spotify expand beyond streaming music. Spotify Technology SA is in talks to purchase podcasting giant Gimlet Media, according to people familiar with the matter, a move that would give a boost to the music-streaming company's narrative-audio ambitions.

title: Virginia's 'Moderate' Governor
summary: Why are some Democrats so eager to demonstrate pro-choice absolutism?. This column is trying to understand the current fad among Democratic state officeholders for enabling abortions right up until the moment of birth. Since the abortion market generally has been in historic decline and the demand for such procedures at the end of a pregnancy is extremely small, it's as if politicos like New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo are determined to demonstrate a sort of ideological zealotry. Perhaps somewhere there is a misguided Republican seeking to affirm his love for the 2nd Amendment by supporting the purchase of bazookas without a background check, but it would hardly represent a strategy for winning elections.

title: Sorry for the Good News
summary: A bang-up jobs report reveals underlying economic strength.. Friday was a bad day in certain media and political precincts as the labor market turned in another gangbuster performance in January. The recession may not be imminent after all, and more people are working and making more money. Apologies to Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren and the writers at Bloomberg for the good news.

title: Spartacus in 2020
summary: Cory Booker makes it official. Will he retreat from school choice?. Here's the least surprising news of 2019: Cory Booker is running for President. "Together, we will channel our common pain back into our common purpose," the New Jersey Senator said Friday in a launch video. "Together, America, we will rise." That last part rings like an echo of Barack Obama's old slogan, "Yes we can."

title: When Arms Control Fails
summary: The U.S. leaves the INF treaty after a decade of Russian violations.. The Trump Administration on Friday said it is officially withdrawing from the 1987 INF arms-control treaty after more than a decade of Russian deception and denial. Arms control with adversaries rarely works, and it's impossible when Washington ignores blatant violations.

title: Dollar Edges Higher After Jobs Report
summary: Currency strengthens following its biggest monthly decline in a year. The U.S. dollar rose Friday, bouncing after completing its biggest monthly decline in a year and following 10-year Treasury yields higher.

title: Judges Weigh FCC's Net Neutrality Rollback in High-Stakes Internet Case
summary: Court weighs wholesale changes made after Republicans took over the agency. WASHINGTON-A federal appeals court spent more than four hours on Friday weighing challenges to a federal regulator's rollback of Obama-era net-neutrality rules, a case with high stakes for internet regulation.

title: 1MDB Scandal Could Hit Pay for Goldman Execs, Including Lloyd Blankfein
summary: New Chief Executive David Solomon, others also could have compensation withheld. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. could withhold millions of dollars in pay from former chief Lloyd Blankfein because of the scandal around a corrupt Malaysian investment fund, the bank said Friday.

title: Vice, BuzzFeed and the Reckoning for New-Media Companies
summary: Vice Media layoffs add to upheaval in a sector that once seemed to have mastered digital-media growth. Companies like Vice Media and BuzzFeed not long ago were media-industry darlings, attracting young online audiences, popularizing edgy advertising tactics and drawing billions of investment dollars.

title: Wells Fargo Breaks Down Internal Audit Silos to Fend Off Scandals
summary: Changes to the 'third line of defense' are meant to address previous gaps in oversight. Wells Fargo & Co.'s 103-page business-standards report, released this week to address changes the bank has made in response to a string of scandals, revealed nuanced changes to the company's system of internal checks.

title: Trump Signals Decision on Border Emergency Could Come Soon
summary: President criticizes Pelosi amid lack of progress on immigration talks. WASHINGTON-President Trump suggested Friday he is moving closer to invoking a national emergency to build a border wall and teased a possible announcement next week, while ramping up his criticism of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi over Democrats' refusal to back funding for the barrier.

title: Physics, Biology and Economic Inequality
summary: Adrian Bejan's revolutionary theory proposes that the same laws of nature produce rivers, trees, human beings and wealth distributions.. Durham, N.C.

title: Notable & Quotable: Bay Area Needles
summary: 'San Francisco has more drug addicts than it has students enrolled in its public high schools.'. Phil Matierwriting for the San Francisco Chronicle, Jan. 30:

title: California's Liberal Governor Hauls a Conservative City to Court
summary: To solve a problem made in Sacramento, Newsom asks judges to intervene in local zoning decisions.. California Gov. Gavin Newsom made a down payment on his promise to address the Golden State's housing challenges last week by suing Huntington Beach, a predominantly Republican redoubt in Orange County. The city's crime? Rezoning a parcel of land to restrict low-income housing. "Some cities are refusing to do their part to address this [housing] crisis and willfully stand in violation of California law," Mr. Newsom proclaimed.

title: Howard Schultz Is Right About Medicare for All
summary: If it works in Scandinavia, it won't work in the U.S. because Americans won't pay the required taxes.. For progressives, the only thing worse than Starbucks founder Howard Schultz getting into the 2020 presidential race might be Donald Trump suffering a debilitating heart attack. That's how many on the left secretly see things. To them, Mr. Trump is like another Kennedy assassination combined with another Goldwater-a one-time alignment that will enable an agenda that otherwise would never get through the White House door. Item No. 1 on that agenda is single-payer health care.

title: Behavioral Economics May Make Champs of the Cleveland Browns
summary: Following the advice of an academic paper, the team improved from 0-16 in 2017 to 7-8-1 last year.. All eyes are on the Los Angeles Rams and the New England Patriots, but the Cleveland Browns had an impressive season too. Although they didn't make the playoffs, they did go 7-8-1 in 2018 after finishing 0-16 a year earlier. It's one of the biggest single-season improvements in National Football League history, and the Browns owe it in large part to behavioral economics.

title: U.S. Says Americans Can Buy Venezuelan Oil Until April 28
summary: Treasury's sanctions guidance covers Citgo Petroleum, which is controlled by Venezuela's state-owned oil company. The U.S. will allow Americans to buy oil and oil products from Venezuela's state oil company until April 28, the Treasury Department said Friday.

title: 'Hell' Review: The Wholly Lost Below
summary: Alasdair Gray's novel 'Lanark' was a Scottish 'Divine Comedy.' It has long seemed the author's fate to do Dante into English.. A classic is a book that never grows old, but a translation of a classic is not quite as timeless. The most common reason given for retranslating classics is that previous translations are dated or stale; even the most faithful rendering is a product of the language and culture of its time, so eventually we need a fresh one.

title: 'Where Reasons End' Review: Her Son's Afterlife
summary: Yiyun Li turns a tragic personal loss into a profoundly intimate work of fiction.. Yiyun Li dislikes the word "I." "It is a melodramatic word," she explained in a memoir from 2017. "Living is not an original business." Her distaste for drawing attention to herself is apparent in her nonfiction, which can feel abstract and remote, as if she were trying to hide behind big ideas and meticulous sentences. It is in her novels that Ms. Li's thoughts and feelings are most vivid and alive. The form seems to liberate her from concerns about divulging too much. Nowhere is this more clear than in "Where Reasons End," in which Ms. Li turns a tragic personal loss into a profoundly intimate work of fiction.

title: Soybean Futures Rise on China Purchase Plans
summary: Order for 5 million tons of beans won't ease record U.S. stockpiles. Soybean futures climbed after China agreed to purchase 5 million tons of the oilseed from the U.S., though agricultural officials are skeptical the deal wouldmuch dent a projected record U.S. soybean stockpile.

title: Foxconn to Stick With Wisconsin Manufacturing Plant
summary: Company says it will build an LCD factory in Wisconsin, two days after saying constructing such a plant would be economically unfeasible. Foxconn Technology Group, a major supplier to Apple Inc., said Friday that it has decided go ahead with the construction of a liquid-crystal display factory in Wisconsin, two days after saying building such a plant would be economically unfeasible.

title: Duke Energy Broke Rules Designed to Keep Electric Grid Safe
summary: Agency seeks record $10 million fine for serious violations of regulations aimed at preventing physical and cyber attacks. Duke Energy Corp. faces a record $10 million fine from federal authorities for serious and pervasive violations of rules designed to keep the nation's electric system safe from physical and cyber attacks, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Dow Climbs on Strong Earnings Reports From Exxon, Chevron
summary: Robust jobs report supports the newfound optimism in the U.S. economy that has washed over the stock market in the new year. Big gains by energy behemoths Exxon Mobil and Chevron lifted the Dow Jones Industrial Average Friday, helping the index secure its sixth consecutive week of gains.

title: Treasurys Fall on Strong Jobs, Manufacturing Data
summary: Data suggests that there is little reason for investors to expect the U.S. economy will slow down. U.S. government bond prices fell Friday after economic data showed the labor market remained robust and manufacturing rebounded in January.

title: The Positive Results of U.S. War in Vietnam
summary: Mr. Stearman seems to be putting lipstick on a pig.. William Lloyd Stearman's retrospective look at the Vietnam conflict has some significant omissions ("America Lost Vietnam but Saved Southeast Asia," op-ed, Jan. 28). Our involvement in Vietnam began after World War II when we gave financial assistance to France in its effort to hold on to Indochina as a colony. This was contrary to the 1941 Atlantic Charter which said that people should have the right to choose their own form of government. Colonization wouldn't be supported in the postwar era. When the French were defeated in 1954, we gradually moved in. We weren't supporting a legitimate, elected Vietnamese government but a corrupt one with little popular support. In addition, our invasion of Cambodia facilitated the Khmer Rouge takeover and the horrible genocide that followed.

title: Parsing the Numbers on Trump's Border Wall
summary: If every one of the 63 million people who voted for President Trump kicked in $90.50, he'd have his $5.7 billion.. Regarding "The Numbers: Some Other Ways to Measure $5.7 Billion" (U.S. News, Jan. 26): Let's account for the fact that a border structure should last at least 10 years. The apprehensions of undocumented immigrants over 10 years would total 3,040,000 rather than an annual number of 304,000. That's about $1,875 per immigrant rather than $18,750. Similarly, 99,035 annual asylum seekers would be 990,350 over 10 years or $5,756 each rather than $57,555. Other annual comparisons also should be multiplied by 10: 10 years of White House staff expense, 10 years of gross domestic product, 10 years of border-patrol salaries, etc. Whatever side of the immigration debate you are on, we should all agree that reasonable assumptions need to go into the number crunching or the results are nothing more than hyperbole.

title: Pass Real Budgets on Time to End Federal Shutdowns
summary: The answer is to deny a paycheck to all those not doing their jobs.. With all due respect to Ohio Sen. Rob Portman ("Let's End Government Shutdowns for Good," Letters, Jan. 30), the solution isn't to continue appropriating money because that is what continuing resolutions do. The answer isn't to deny public nonessential workers a paycheck, as they were doing their jobs as required. The answer is to deny a paycheck to all those not doing their jobs, which would include all of Congress and the president, until a compromise is reached-and no one is allowed to leave until the job is done. I believe this is why we elected them.

title: Time for an Anti-Taliban Social-Justice Movement
summary: Afghanistan needs its own social-justice warriors.. Regarding Fawzia Koofi's "The Afghan Taliban Stage a Comeback" (op-ed, Jan, 29): Afghanistan needs its own social-justice warriors. If the overwhelming majority of the citizenry truly gives the Taliban no sympathy, then they should be aghast that their government is even entertaining negotiating with it. Instead, they should be in the streets and villages shaming, banishing and labeling the oppressive beliefs of the Taliban taboo. To be labeled a Taliban sympathizer should carry the same shame as being called a white supremacist in America. Another 18 years of American intervention will only prolong the dire need for the Afghan people to finally stand up for themselves.

title: Prosecutors Seek October Trial Date for Stone; Judge Weighs Gag Order
summary: The amount of material, complexity of charges cited in trial date request. WASHINGTON-Lawyers for the government proposed an October trial date for Trump adviser Roger Stone on charges that he tried to impede a congressional investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

title: 'An Enumeration' Means Counting, not Guessing
summary: Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross's decision to ask the citizenship question has solid legal backing.. Regarding your editorial "Who Runs the Census?" (Jan. 25): I suspect that the Census Bureau's career staff-with virtually lifetime tenure-much prefer "running a mishmash of data . . . through statistical models" because it empowers their agency and makes them nearly indispensable. But the Founders chose otherwise. Article I, Section 2 of the Constitution requires an "actual Enumeration" every 10 years. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross's decision to ask the citizenship question has solid legal backing: Count, don't estimate.

title: VIX Auction Bets Land Chicago Trader With $1.3 Million Fine
summary: Cboe fines Akuna Securities for trying to affect monthly auction tied to the VIX volatility gauge. Cboe Global Markets Inc. fined a trading firm for trying to include improper options trades in an auction tied to its marquee product: the VIX volatility gauge.

title: Inspectors of Collapsed Brazilian Dam Had Close Ties to Its Owner
summary: Deadly incident raises fresh questions over whether the dual role of safety evaluator and consultant presents a conflict of interest that can compromise safety. The company that certified the safety of a Brazilian waste dam that collapsed last week, killing at least 115 people, has worked as both a consultant and an independent safety evaluator for the dam's owner, raising questions among experts over potential conflicts of interest.

title: Johns Hopkins Presses for Armed Campus Police Force
summary: University points to high crime rates while critics worry about accountability. BALTIMORE-Johns Hopkins University is seeking state approval to create an armed police force, something that many urban universities have but has sparked some objections here.

title: Oil Prices Reach Two-Month High on Lower Supply
summary: OPEC output declines, Venezuelan turmoil, and a robust U.S. jobs market boost crude prices. HIGHLIGHTS

title: 'Z' Is for the Post-Millennial Generation
summary: The trend in naming age cohorts is just to use letters. Now we've reached the end of the alphabet. What's next?. The Pew Research Center, a nonprofit group that specializes in measuring public opinion across demographic groups, recently announced that it had settled on what to call the "post-millennial" generation born from about 1997 to 2012. Taking its cue from popular usage, Pew will apply the label "Generation Z," or "Gen Z" for short.

title: Economy Notches 100th Straight Month of Increased Employment
summary: Nonfarm payrolls rose a seasonally adjusted 304,000 in January. WASHINGTON-The U.S. labor market notched its 100th straight month of increased employment in January while sustaining robust wage growth, passing the tests posed by a federal-government shutdown, market volatility and uncertainty about global economies.

title: 4K vs. 8K: Which TV Is Right for You?
summary: Just as 4KTV content starts to infiltrate homes, 8K is rearing its gorgeous head. The higher resolution will astound you, but you may well wonder if it's time to make the leap. JUST LAST YEAR, I bought a 65-inch 4K TV. It has a gorgeous picture: deep blacks and dynamic, true-to-life colors. I can finally watch all that 4K ultrahigh definition (UHD) content newly on offer from Netflix, Prime Video and iTunes. It's a glorious thing, and it feels a lot like the early days of high definition: Everything is deliciously detailed, real, beautiful.

title: Herman Cain Says Consideration for Fed Would Be an Honor
summary: White House official dismisses Cain's candidacy as 'not serious'. Former Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain said he would be honored to considered by President Trump for a Federal Reserve job, though a White House official said Mr. Cain's candidacy for the central-bank board is "not serious."

title: Finding Grace in a Grim Setting
summary: Olivier Messiaen's hauntingly mysterious 'Quartet for the End of Time' came to life not in a church but in a World War II Nazi prisoner-of-war camp, yet it is teeming with religious ardor..

title: Northwestern University Picks Economist to Steer M.B.A. Program
summary: Francesca Cornelli of the London Business School to join the Kellogg School of Management in August. Northwestern University named Francesca Cornelli as the new dean of its Kellogg School of Management, taking over the M.B.A. program.

title: Senator Pushes for End to Government Control of Fannie, Freddie
summary: Sen. Mike Crapo urged lawmakers to 'expeditiously fix our flawed housing-finance system'. WASHINGTON-Sen. Mike Crapo on Friday pushed to end government control of mortgage-finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, kicking off a complex legislative process that had previously failed to attract enough congressional support.

title: Logistics, Parcel Hiring Soared in January
summary: The payrolls growth after the holidays comes as digital commerce demands are extending the season for shopping and returns. Transportation and logistics companies defied a usual postholiday slowdown by hiring in big numbers last month, including a strong expansion in payrolls at warehouse and parcel operations.

title: Copper Edges Lower After Weak Chinese Economic Data
summary: Prices have rallied recently but are still off more than 15% from their June four-year highs. Copper prices inched lower Friday, hurt by another round of weak economic data from China.

title: Indian Government Rebuts Accusations It Cooked Books to Boost Election Prospects
summary: Two top statisticians resigned this week to protest how the government has been handling economic-data releases. NEW DELHI-The Indian government has rushed to defend itself against accusations it was tampering with indicators to make the economy look healthier as the country heads toward elections.

title: Products Yanked from Amazon in India as New Rules Take Effect
summary: Earlier workarounds to existing restrictions are no longer adequate; Walmart's Flipkart also scrambles. MUMBAI-Thousands of products were pulled from Amazon.com Inc.'s India website Friday-the first direct impact from the country's new e-commerce rules, a day after warning the restrictions would hurt its business there.

title: A Cozy Ski House With Midcentury Modern Spirit
summary: For an idiosyncratic ski home in Utah, a family and their designers take inspiration from the irrepressible textile prints of Josef Frank. When a San Francisco couple bought a slick, somewhat masculine, newly built condo in Park City, Utah, their designers knew it wouldn't satisfy its intended purpose as a welcoming family ski home. "We wanted to make it happy," said Chloe Warner, of Redmond Aldrich Design in Oakland, Calif. She and her associate Taylor Shanahan started with knowledge that the new owners felt an affinity for the lush, vibrant patterns of Josef Frank, the 20th-century Austrian-born architect and textile designer. Next, they invented a narrative to guide their decisions: What if Frank had a chic granddaughter named Heidi, with all that name's alpine connotations, who had come to America for a year abroad and stayed? What would her home look like? The designers then articulated Frank's aesthetic-vegetal, happy, alpine, botanical-and let those words guide them. "That's how you wind up with something new instead of a copy, or a 'Look, it's a Josef Frank house!'" said Ms. Warner.

title: Tom Brady Really Is Bad for Your Portfolio
summary: In terms of total returns, a Rams victory bodes well for stocks. Stock market pros roll their eyes at the so-called Super Bowl Indicator-and no wonder.

title: Mining Mogul Agarwal Sells Rights to Large Anglo American Stake
summary: The ownership of the underlying shares, and the associated voting interest, remain with Mr. Agarwal's family trust. Mining mogul Anil Agarwal has sold the rights to a large stake in mining giant Anglo American to Vedanta, the Indian resources group he is the majority owner in.

title: KKR Reports Fourth-Quarter Loss
summary: Market turmoil leads to an investment loss of $798.1 million for the private-equity firm. KKR & Co. on Friday posted a fourth-quarter loss, mirroring results from its peers earlier in the week, as market turmoil took a toll on its portfolio.

title: Cigna Expects Minimal Impact From Drug-Rebate Proposal
summary: Insurer gives conservative guidance for 2019, the first year including Express Scripts. Cigna Corp. said a new federal proposal that would curb rebates from drugmakers would have minimal impact on its results and offered conservative earnings guidance for 2019, the first year it will include the operations of Express Scripts Holding Co.

title: A One-of-a-Kind British Country Inn: Worth the Wait?
summary: We scrutinized Heckfield Place, a newly opened luxury estate in Hampshire and found a whole other breed of country house-both eco-conscious and sumptuous. WELCOME TO the new age of old English countryside hotels. Among the slew of openings is a deluxe manse for every taste. Bohemian aristocrats will want to rest at Durslade Farmhouse, an elegant six-bedroom relic on the grounds of Hauser & Wirth Somerset, the Swiss dealers' sprawling art center. Clubby sorts might make a sortie to Oxfordshire's Soho Farmhouse. Tux owners? Their black-tie-optional ideal might be the Langley, a 41-room inn with 18th-century Capability Brown gardens in Buckinghamshire, set to open this spring. Of all the new arrivals, none has teased Londoners as long as Heckfield Place, opened last fall after nine years in the making. A 400-acre self-sustaining luxury estate in Hampshire-about 60 minutes by train from the capital-the retreat was exactingly made over by owner Gerald Chan (a Hong Kong-born, Boston-based real estate mogul), and spares no frills but isn't frilly at all. Here, a closer, critical look:

title: Cigna's $54 Billion Problem
summary: Health insurer's purchase of Express Scripts is looking like even more of a blunder. Cigna has more work to do if it wants to convince investors that its $54 billion deal was a good idea.

title: Danish Drugmaker Expects Higher Working Capital as Brexit Looms
summary: Novo Nordisk says it is piling up insulin products in the U.K., on rising concerns about tariff and cross-border freight. Danish insulin maker Novo Nordisk A/S is forecasting a rise in the working capital it would need as it prepares for a potentially disruptive Brexit, including product stockpiles and alternative means of drug transportation.

title: Stocks to Watch: Exxon, Amazon, CVS, Deckers Outdoor, 1-800 Flowers
summary: Resume Subscription. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Fed's Kaplan: Fed Likely On Pause Until At Least Summer
summary: 'It's very important for the Fed to get out of the way' and let the economy work through some issues, the Dallas Fed president says. Dallas Federal Reserve Bank President Robert Kaplan said he believes the U.S. central bank will hold off on rate increases until at least the summer.

title: NYC Councilman Taken Into Custody by Police After Neighbors Complain
summary: Officials say Bill Perkins was 'acting erratically' and was admitted to a local hospital. New York City Councilman Bill Perkins was taken into custody by New York Police Department officers on Thursday night for "acting erratically" and was admitted to a local hospital, police officials said.

title: Five Ways to Pay for Grad School
summary: Resume Subscription. Many students seeking graduate degrees need help footing the bill. But they often don't know where to turn.

title: China Counts the Costs of Its Big Bet on Venezuela
summary: Beijing weighs its options as it stands behind a government that still owes it $20 billion. BEIJING-When China hatched the first of a series of oil-for-loans agreements with Venezuela in 2007, it seemed like a perfect match. Venezuela had the world's biggest oil reserves; China was poised to become the biggest energy consumer.

title: An Awkward Jobs Report for the Fed
summary: The Federal Reserve said the case for raising rates had weakened. Then came the jobs report.. The Federal Reserve just told us it isn't planning any more rate increases. The job market may have something to say about that.

title: Consumer Sentiment Hits Lowest Level in More Than Two Years
summary: The partial government shutdown drove much of January's stark decline. WASHINGTON-Household sentiment in the U.S. fell sharply in January, as the partial government shutdown and uncertain economic prospects weighed on consumers.

title: During Shutdown, Federal Employees Considered Leaving Government Work
summary: Budget fight and resulting worker furloughs touched off wave of searches on job websites. WASHINGTON-The longest federal government shutdown on record left some employees wondering if they should leave the public sector altogether.

title: Exxon's Lost Decade Has Left It Cheap
summary: Exxon Mobil's transformation into an industrial giant extracting profit from the U.S. shale boom hasn't been reflected in its share price. A decade ago, Exxon Mobil was the most valuable company on earth. Since then, its shares have gone nowhere, lagging the S&P 500 by 231 percentage points.

summary: A behavioral economist answers questions on telling lies, green incentives and leaving friends behind. Dear Dan,

title: U.S. Factory-Sector Growth Accelerated in January
summary: Demand and output overrode uncertainty surrounding partial government shutdown. WASHINGTON-Growth picked up for U.S. manufacturers in January, a sign strong factory-sector demand and output overrode uncertainty surrounding the partial government shutdown in the first month of the year.

title: Two Sisters Bought DNA Kits. The Results Blew Apart Their Family.
summary: In an age of ubiquitous direct-to-consumer genetic testing, family secrets are almost impossible to keep.. Sonny and Brina Hurwitz raised a family in Boston. They both died with secrets.

title: EU Struggles to Reach United Response to Venezuelan Crisis
summary: Bloc prefers to present a united front in response to major international matters but can't find consensus on recognizing Juan Guaidó as interim president. BUCHAREST-A group of European countries is set to recognize Venezuela's opposition leader as interim president, joining the U.S. and a handful of Latin American countries moving against Nicolás Maduro, even as the European Union struggles to agree a common stance on the Venezuelan crisis.

title: Japan's Top Business Group: China Isn't an Enemy
summary: Hitachi chairman says 'it is impossible for Japan to exist' if country takes hard line against China in trade conflict. TOKYO-China's slowing economy is highlighting the dependence of Japan on its giant neighbor, driving Tokyo's business leaders to take a gentler line than the U.S. in trade conflicts.

summary: A shared rivalry with the U.S. has reunited the two powers, as in the early days of the Cold War. But this time, China is the senior partner..

title: Shutdown Had Little Impact on Strong Jobs Picture
summary: Most labor statistics unaffected; only unemployment rate slightly stirred. The partial government shutdown, which closed many federal offices for a record-setting 35 days, did little to dent a robust U.S. labor market.

title: Apple Apologizes for FaceTime Bug, Sets Fix for Next Week
summary: The glitch was an embarrassment for Apple, which has marketed the security and privacy of its devices and criticized tech rivals for their data collection. Apple Inc. apologized for a security flaw in its FaceTime video-chat system and said a software fix is coming next week, as the iPhone maker sought to assure customers it moved fast to address an embarrassing vulnerability that drew the attention of government officials.

title: Analysis: January Jobs Report Won't Change the Fed's New Wait-and-See Stance
summary: It will take more than one month of solid employment numbers for the Federal Reserve to move again on rates. The strong January employment report offers one promising data point for Federal Reserve officials who are trying to gauge how the U.S. economy weathered increased market volatility and slowing global growth at the end of last year.

title: My Family's Iranian Revolution
summary: The return of the Ayatollah Khomeini in 1979 brought joy at first, then despair and dislocation. When I was a boy, my birthday was the subject of a long-running joke in our family. I was born in Tehran on Feb. 1, 1985-exactly six years to the day that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returned from his Parisian exile to herald the new Islamic Republic of Iran. One of our relatives, a gregarious retired police colonel, would often ask me at our family get-togethers: "When were you born, Sohrab?"

title: Can the Government Help You Save for Retirement?
summary: Lawmakers are looking to expand access to tax-advantaged plans, boost savings rates and enhance long-term income sustainability. In 2018, state and federal lawmakers got serious about retirement security-or the lack thereof. This year should bring continued attention to the issue.

title: Florence Knoll Bassett Gave Corporate Offices a Clean, Modern Look
summary: Designer and architect, influenced by Mies van der Rohe, banished clutter, frills and big boxy desks. Six or seven decades ago, a big shot's office was likely to be dominated by a boxy desk, surrounded by a few unremarkable chairs and perhaps a table stacked with files and knickknacks.

title: Peter Magowan Endured a Bumpy Ride as Head of Safeway
summary: Oxford-educated businessman slashed costs at grocery chain and was caught up in baseball's flap over steroids.

title: Midday Workouts Are Great. Smelly Sneakers Under Your Desk, Not So Much.
summary: Offices are putting in gyms and urging staff to exercise. The pungent consequence: sweaty shoes stashed under desks.. While working as an exhibitions manager at University College London, Susie Chan kept as many as eight pairs of sneakers under her desk, the result of her regular runs before work. Her sweaty running clothes? Draped on chairs and other furniture nearby, airing out to dry.

title: Role Playing on Canvas
summary: In the 20th century, German artists reinvented the self-portrait for an age of historical crisis. In the first half of the 20th century, German-speaking Europe experienced world wars, economic chaos and the rise of Nazism. It was an unlikely historical moment for artists to focus on the most private of genres, the self-portrait. But "The Self-Portrait: From Schiele to Beckmann," a new exhibition that will be on view at New York's Neue Galerie from Feb. 28 to June 24, suggests that this time and place produced the greatest flowering of art depicting the artist since the Renaissance.

title: The Surprising Truth Behind Wine Pricing
summary: In search of well made national-brand wines to recommend, our wine columnist uncovered wheeling and dealing at the wholesale level that profoundly affects who drinks what, where-and for how much. I LIVE IN a wine-rich part of the country, home to many good wine merchants. Some oenophiles, however, live in states where the government controls wine distribution, and thus access to certain brands. Others live far from wine shops and buy their bottles at grocery stores. I know this because I've received many letters from readers over the years requesting recommendations of wines produced in large quantities that are easy to find and also well made and reasonably priced-wines known in the trade as national brands.

title: Children's Books: Handing Out the Hardware
summary: The Newbery and Caldecott winners are lively works that draw on divergent traditions.. The handing out of literary awards is not a science but a subjective art, and the books that end up winning often say something about the cultural moment. That's certainly the case with the 2019 Newbery Medal and Caldecott Medal, which were awarded this week along with Newbery and Caldecott Honor awards for distinguished runners-up.

title: Science Fiction: Charlie Moment's Second Take
summary: In Gregory Benford's novel a washed-up 48-year-old wakes up on his 16th birthday-he'll get to live his life over again, if he can figure out how it all works.. 'If only young men knew, if only old men could." The sad proverb triggers a fantasy imagined by all but the happiest of the middle-aged: If I could just go back and live my life again, knowing what I know now (the vital proviso), then I'd slide through life like a greased eel.

title: Nuclear Pact Breakdown Unnerves U.S. Allies
summary: NATO has endorsed the U.S. assessment of Russia, but some have raised concerns about the start of a new arms race. The U.S. decision to start the process of withdrawing from a decades-old treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces is unsettling Europe, which sits in range of a Russian missile system that U.S. officials say breaches the 1987 pact.

title: Best-Selling Books, Week Ended Jan. 26
summary: With data from NPD BookScan. NPD BookScan gathers point-of-sale book data from more than 16,000 locations across the U.S., representing about 85% of the nation's book sales. Print-book data providers include all major booksellers, web retailers and food stores. E-book data providers include all major e-book retailers. Free e-books and those selling for less than 99 cents are excluded from the ebook lists. The fiction and nonfiction combined lists include aggregated sales for all book formats (except audio books, bundles, boxed sets and foreign language editions) and feature a combination of adult, young adult and juvenile titles. The hardcover fiction and nonfiction lists also encompass a mix of adult, young adult and juvenile titles while the business list features only adult hardcover titles. Refer questions to Teresa.Vozzo@wsj.com.

title: At Work at 20 Below
summary: Resume Subscription. Temperatures across the Midwest dropped near record lows this week, disrupting everything from schools and auto manufacturers to postal delivery and air travel. As many Americans cozied up indoors, some workers with outdoor jobs were less fortunate. The Wall Street Journal asked five brave photographers to find people clocking in and braving the Arctic blast.

title: Halal Restaurants Put Mexican on Menu to Sate Expanding Palates
summary: 'The goal' said the owner of one of the restaurants, is for his Muslim patrons to 'enjoy it without any hesitation'. As a fan of Mexican food, Abul Hashem has often found himself frustrated that many popular menu items at restaurants specializing in the cuisine were off-limits. The reason? Mr. Hashem, a 35-year-old Brooklyn resident who was born in Bangladesh, adheres to the dietary laws of his Muslim faith, otherwise known as halal.

title: The Surprise Super Bowl Ad Is Back in Vogue
summary: After years of releasing big game commercials early, some big brands are keeping them under wraps. For the past several years, many Super Bowl advertisers have released their commercials online days or even weeks in advance, hoping to capitalize on the extra exposure and attention.

title: In Daniel Radcliffe's New TBS Show, the Former Boy Wizard Seeks Comedy Magic
summary: Mr. Radcliffe makes his first major foray into on-screen comedy with 'Miracle Workers' and is also an executive producer for the show. As Harry Potter, actor Daniel Radcliffe was the boy wizard who lived in the cupboard under the stairs. Now, he's an angel working in the basement of heaven.

title: Five Best: Tessa Hadley on Books About Childhood Friendships
summary: The author, most recently, of the novel 'Late in the Day' selects works that portray the early kindlings of fellow-feeling.. By Alexander Herzen (1861)

title: Fiction: We Will Have the Tale
summary: A superhuman bounty hunter at large in an imagined world rooted in African folklore.. Can there be an odyssey without a homecoming? The question is posed-and answered in a roaring affirmative-by Marlon James in his novel "Black Leopard, Red Wolf" (Riverhead, 620 pages, $30), the teeming, blood-dimmed first volume of a planned trilogy. Like some of its characters, the book is a shape-shifter, at times assuming the form of a classic fantasy epic and at others that of something ambiguous and bewildering, a fantastical creature that won't stop moving long enough to submit to classification.

title: 'City of Light' Review: The Man Who Lit Up Paris
summary: Haussmann's projects created the city we know today, but he was brought down by an uproar over the debts the city incurred.. The Grand Paris Express, an ambitious project initiated in 2013 and aimed at doubling the length of the Paris Metro by 2030, should be the envy of cities the world over. In modern Western democracies, many urban residents are resistant to new development in general, let alone such an enormous undertaking. Bold public enterprise has retreated, and visionaries like Baron Georges-Eugène Haussmann-who transformed Paris with dazzling avenues, parks and other lasting renovations between 1853 and 1870-are few and far between. As journalist and critic Rupert Christiansen writes in "City of Light: The Making of Modern Paris," the Grand Paris Express-125 miles of subway lines, more than 90% of them underground, at a cost of $210 million per mile-"would not only have tested Haussmann's managerial skills but also thrilled his stony heart." For Paris is steeped in the tradition of grand public works, a tradition begun in earnest by Haussmann, who was the first to see and plan Paris as a city rather than merely an agglomeration of urban villages.

title: 'The Inflamed Mind' Review: Looking in the Wrong Place
summary: So far there is no blood test or 'biomarker' researchers can look for to identify a propensity for depression.. The cover of "The Inflamed Mind" should immediately arouse a reader's suspicions about the reliability of what lies within. The subtitle promises "a radical new approach to depression," and the front flap of the dust jacket claims this is a "game-changing" book that "reveals the breakthrough new science on the link between depression and inflammation of the body and brain." In science, the words "radical," "game-changing" and "breakthrough" apply to vanishingly few developments. Scientists despair of the way language like this excites the public-only to dampen enthusiasm when, after a few years, the breakthrough hasn't actually broken through anything and the game hasn't changed. The public is left feeling sour not only about the promised radical new treatment but also about how science works.

title: 'The Popol Vuh' Review: A New World Epic
summary: A lively new translation of the great Maya creation myth, a rare survival from the pre-Columbus Americas.. The literature of ancient America is mostly lost to us today, except for a few scattered remnants of poems, histories and myths that survived the onslaught of European contact and its waves of cultural destruction. What little we know comes from what early chroniclers happened to write down, from what indigenous people could retain in their own oral and written traditions, or from newly deciphered hieroglyphic texts from Mesoamerica, where writing and literacy developed 2,000 years before Columbus's caravels appeared on the horizon. Of all of these tantalizing remains perhaps none is more important and profound than the "Popol Vuh," the epic account of world creation as told by the K'iche' Maya people of Guatemala, available in a new and accessible verse translation by Michael Bazzett.

title: 'Milk of Paradise' Review: The Growth of a Global Problem
summary: Opium has been yielding vast profits and sparking stubborn conflict since prehistoric times.. Lucy Inglis is a respected historian of 18th-century London who curates a blog about the back stories of England's capital and lives in the shadows of Christopher Wren's cathedral of St. Paul. Introducing "Milk of Paradise: A History of Opium," she explains that her experience as a caregiver administering morphine to dying family members and watching medically prescribed heroin bring peaceful death through respiratory failure interested her in the history of opiates. "I have been impossibly grateful for a drug that allowed them to continue to live well," she writes, "even as they were in the process of dying."

title: 'Lady First' Review: The Inside Game
summary: For the better part of two decades, Sarah Childress Polk was the most powerful woman in America.. James Polk owed his presidency to two people-Andrew Jackson, his political mentor, and Sarah Childress Polk, his political partner. For the better part of two decades, Sarah was the most powerful woman in America. "Her political power," Amy S. Greenberg writes in "Lady First: The World of First Lady Sarah Polk," "stemmed not from the ability to vote but from [learning] . . . that female deference not only had its privileges, but could also, under the right circumstances, be mobilized for political ends." She became, one might say, a master mobilizer.

title: 'Quarterback' Review: An Endless Arms Race
summary: Thirty years ago, only about 50% of passing plays resulted in a gain of yards; today nearly 65% do. The sport's most important position just keeps getting more important.. In politics, presidents get too much credit when things go well and too much blame when things do not. The same goes for the National Football League, where rule changes and economics keep making the quarterback ever-more important. To be successful in today's game, there is having a franchise-quality quarterback, and then there is everything else.

title: The History of a Cold War Missile Treaty
summary: INF Treaty is at risk of collapsing and fueling a new arms race. Here is a look at its history. The Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty, one of the linchpins in the arms-control framework that helped seal the end of the Cold War, is at risk of collapsing and fueling a new arms race.

title: Deutsche Bank Disappoints as Future Remains in Question
summary: Fourth-quarter loss deepens despite a return to annual profit, as speculation builds about Deutsche Bank's future as a standalone lender. FRANKFURT-Deutsche Bank AG posted a steeper-than-expected fourth-quarter loss and vowed to cut costs more aggressively as the embattled bank struggles to quell persistent speculation about its future.

title: Deutsche Bank Needs to Evade Bad News Bears
summary: It has found a floor in its lending operation, but needs to find one in investment banking. Only one question matters for Deutsche Bank at this point: Has it found the bottom?

title: The Super Bowl That Launched the Patriots' Dynasty
summary: This Super Bowl is the culmination of everything that has happened to these two franchises in the years since they played for the Lombardi Trophy in 2002. ATLANTA-The organization the New England Patriots beat to begin their dynasty now has the chance to be the ultimate spoiler.

title: Goodell Vanished, Football Reappeared, NFL Ratings Rose
summary: The NFL's commissioner, so frequently at the center of attention and controversy in the past, has conspicuously kept a low profile during a season when attention shifted to high-scoring games and young stars. ATLANTA-Something has been missing from the NFL's great comeback season of 2018: Commissioner Roger Goodell.

title: Fans of the Super Bowl-Based Market Predictor Are Betting on the Rams
summary: The indicator may not be based on science, but it's still better than most on Wall Street. Bullish investors who look at an unscientific but popular indicator will be rooting for the Los Angeles Rams on Sunday when they face the New England Patriots in the Super Bowl.

title: Facebook Removes Accounts of Fake-News Group in Indonesia
summary: Social-media company cites 'coordinated abuse of the platform' in banning Saracen Group. JAKARTA, Indonesia- Facebook Inc. removed hundreds of accounts, groups and pages linked to an online syndicate that has been accused of spreading fake news and hate speech in Indonesia, less than three months before a presidential election in the world's third-largest democracy.

title: Fans Flip Out Over NFL Rule. Is It Fair?
summary: As luck would have it, the Patriots called heads, then beat the Chiefs in overtime.

title: Digital First Hires Financial Adviser to Press Gannett Bid
summary: USA Today owner's board met Thursday to discuss offer; parties may talk next week. Gannett Co. suitor Digital First Media has hired a financial adviser as it seeks to press its $1.4 billion bid for the USA Today publisher.

title: Facebook Is Flying Too High Again
summary: Social-media giant faces many challenges, and its record quarterly profit won't wipe them away. Facebook's solid fourth-quarter results may have assuaged investors' fears, but Wall Street's newfound enthusiasm for the social network seems to ignore the fact that many significant challenges lie ahead.

title: Honeywell Swings to Profit
summary: Results were bolstered by strong demand in the conglomerate's U.S. defense, warehouse automation and aerospace businesses. Honeywell International Inc. swung to a profit in the fourth quarter on continued strong demand for its U.S. defense, warehouse-automation and aerospace businesses.

title: Why GE Shouldn't Jettison Jet-Leasing
summary: Selling planes is still good business, but selling the unit that owns them may not be. Aircraft leasing might sound like the kind of opaque financial business General Electric could do without, but chief executive Larry Culp is probably right to keep it. If he needs cash, he can sell some of its 1,900 jets.

title: Journalists Jailed by Myanmar Appeal to Supreme Court
summary: Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo were sentenced to seven years in prison after reporting on a massacre by the military. Lawyers for two Reuters journalists jailed in Myanmar after reporting on a massacre by its military appealed their convictions to the country's Supreme Court.

title: Sony May Need a New PlayStation Soon
summary: Sales of the PS4 slowed despite discounted prices during the holiday season. Sony reported another quarter of record profit, but weakness is bubbling just below the surface.

title: Microsoft's Resurgence Under Satya Nadella
summary: In Davos, the CEO reflects on his tenure, dealing with competitors and the tech industry's image problem. DAVOS, Switzerland-When Satya Nadella took Microsoft Corp.'s helm five years ago, the conventional wisdom was that the company's glory days were behind it. Its ubiquitous Windows system was losing its primacy and a costly bet on acquiring Nokia 's mobile-phone business had failed to pay off. Microsoft's stock had stagnated for a decade.

title: Democratic Lawmaker Labors to Avoid Another Shutdown
summary: Rep. Nita Lowey has two weeks to cajole legislators into a spending deal that Trump would sign.

title: Sen. Cory Booker Launches Presidential Campaign
summary: The former mayor of Newark becomes the fourth Senate Democrat to join the field of challengers to President Trump. New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker entered the race for the Democratic presidential nomination on Friday, aiming to offer a message of unity in a growing field of Democrats opposing President Trump.

title: Corporate China Faces Wave of Losses
summary: Companies are suffering from declining revenues, higher costs and a surge in write-downs on assets. SHANGHAI-The largest number of Chinese public companies in a decade expect to incur annual losses after a weak economy hit businesses and eroded asset values.

title: For Many British Pets After a No-Deal Brexit: Staycations
summary: Pet passports issued by the EU won't be recognized for U.K. critters anymore if there is a hard Brexit. LONDON-Among those taking precautions in case of an abrupt and messy break between the U.K. and the European Union are David Adams and his guide dog, Jimbo, a 19-month-old Labrador retriever.

title: With Cash Handouts, India Takes Step Toward Universal Basic Income
summary: Government promises payouts to help hundreds of millions of small farmers. NEW DELHI-India unveiled huge handouts for farmers, setting the stage for an election-year spending spree, a possible prelude to implementing a universal basic income in an effort to deal with widespread poverty.

title: A Visual Guide to Brexit
summary: Britain's decision to leave the EU-and the uncertainty it unleashed-has pummeled the country's currency, markets and financial sector. Track its impact in charts and graphics.. The clock is running down to the U.K.'s scheduled departure from the European Union on March 29, but Brexit's impact has been ricocheting across the country's markets, currency and major industries since the vote to break away from the trading bloc in 2016.

title: Raising Your Own Rates Even if the Fed Won't
summary: Resume Subscription. The Federal Reserve signaled on Wednesday that it will be "patient" before raising interest rates again, but you should put your money in motion.

title: Secret Truck Routes and Backup Storage: One Firm's Brexit Crisis Plan
summary: Like hundreds of other companies in Britain, a German machine-tools maker prepared an emergency plan, but now wonders whether to trigger it. REDDITCH, England-Matthias Meyer's emergency Brexit plan-from a secret truck route to extra storage space and pre-booked ferry transportation-has been ready for months.

title: Sherrod Brown Casts Himself as Progressive Before It Was Cool
summary: Pointing to his lengthy record in the House and the Senate, the Ohio Democrat believes he can also win back Trump voters. CRESCO, Iowa-Ohio Sen. Sherrod Brown, contemplating jumping into a growing Democratic presidential primary dominated thus far by candidates from coastal, liberal enclaves, is sharpening his pitch in this early-voting state as a Midwesterner who can appeal to progressives and Trump supporters.

title: The Real Streaming Race Starts... Now
summary: Netflix jockeys to maintain position as rivals from Apple to Comcast add original content, apply pricing pressure. This media battle will be binge-worthy.

title: Jubilant January: What a Difference a Month Makes in Markets
summary: Stocks in the U.S. posted their best starts in decades; emerging markets did even better. Global markets have had a strong start to the year, with equities gaining around the world, credit spreads falling on corporate debt, and emerging-market currencies strengthening as expectations fade of further increases in official U.S. interest rates.

title: With China, Trump Risks Wasting a Crisis
summary: A face-saving trade deal might boost markets in the short run, but both the U.S. and China would benefit from a tougher line. Whispers of a possible deal are emerging from the U.S.-China trade talks in Washington. President Trump still has the upper hand. The question is whether he will use it-or settle for a face-saving deal to boost markets and shore up his rural constituency.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: NYC Housing Chief to Leave de Blasio Administration
summary: Maria Torres-Springer to join Ford Foundation, latest in series of top-level departures. Maria Torres-Springer, who has led New York City's housing-development agency for the past two years-her third top post in Mayor Bill de Blasio's administration-is leaving city government to take a job in the private sector.

title: Intel's New CEO Advances From CFO Spot a Second Time
summary: Just 6.8% of sitting CEOs made the leap to CEO from the CFO role-and even fewer make that trip twice. Bob Swan, Intel Corp.'s new chief executive, is now a two-time member of an exclusive club of former finance chiefs who have ascended to the top leadership spot-a reaffirmation of his expansive management skill set, executive consultants said.

title: Apple Exerts Power as Privacy Protector
summary: iPhone maker punishes Google, Facebook over violations of its developer policies governing personal data. Apple Inc. is flexing its power as a self-appointed privacy protector, punishing Google and Facebook Inc. over violations of its developer policies governing personal data in moves that harden battle lines over one of the technology industry's most sensitive issues.

title: Judge Allows Manhattan Congestion Charge on Taxi Rides to Start
summary: Legal challenge by taxi drivers and owners of medallions over fee to continue. Taxi and for-hire passengers will pay a congestion charge on trips in the busiest parts of New York City after a state court judge on Thursday lifted a temporary restriction on the fee.

title: Pentagon Sending 3,500 More Troops to Mexico Border
summary: House committee leader reveals plan in letter blasting Pentagon for secrecy. The U.S. military plans to more than double the number of active-duty forces at the southern border, with the new figure disclosed in a letter from a congressional leader admonishing the Pentagon.

title: In North Korea Talks, U.S. Says It Is Willing to Wait on Key Objectives
summary: Pace of diplomacy quickens, as President Trump says he and North Korea's Kim have agreed to meet in February. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration on Thursday outlined its goals for next month's summit with North Korea, saying it will defer some of its most stringent demands on North Korea while stressing that the U.S. is willing to reciprocate.

title: Herman Cain, Marvin Goodfriend Being Considered for Fed Governor
summary: Both the former presidential candidate and the Carnegie Mellon economist are among candidates for two Federal Reserve vacancies. Former presidential candidate and restaurant executive Herman Cain is being considered by President Trump for one of two vacancies on the Federal Reserve's board of governors, a top White House adviser said Thursday.

title: U.S. Moves to Curb Drug Rebates in Medicare, Medicaid
summary: Proposal, likely to draw industry resistance, would limit rebates drugmakers give to third parties. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration on Thursday proposed curbing billions of dollars in annual rebates that drugmakers give middlemen in Medicare, a move it said would drive down the prices consumers pay for prescription drugs.

title: On Brink of Arms Treaty Exit, U.S. Finds More Offending Russian Missiles
summary: Moscow has expanded its deployment of a nuclear missile system the U.S. says violates a 1987 pact, according to Western officials. Russia has expanded its deployment of a missile system the U.S. says violates a 1987 treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces, widening the differences with Washington over a pact the U.S. is expected to exit on Saturday, Western officials said.

title: Amazon Reports Third Record Profit in a Row
summary: Shares slide in after-hours trading as company flags uncertainty in India and possible uptick in spending. Amazon.com Inc. recorded a third straight record profit, but uncertainty in India and a possible uptick in spending threaten to cut short that streak.

title: Trump Gives Upbeat Assessment of Trade Talks With China
summary: Trump and Xi to meet in late February, Beijing offers to boost soybean purchases. WASHINGTON-The U.S. and China moved closer to settling their trade dispute, with President Trump saying he expects to meet again with Chinese President Xi Jinping to resolve the conflict that has rattled the global economy.

title: When Politicians Direct Capital
summary: PG&E's bankruptcy shows the peril of the public utility model.. Elizabeth Warren wants to remake corporations into de facto public utilities. For a window on how that will turn out, look at the many failures of California utility PG&E , whose bankruptcy this week illustrates the dangers of politicians directing business investment.

title: Judicial Scramble Drill
summary: The White House walks away from a bad deal but harms a good nominee.. Our editorial Wednesday on White House negotiations with California Democrats over judicial nominees struck a nerve, and it's good to know we get results. The Trump Team appears to have backed off this bad idea, though not without treating one nominee as collateral damage.

title: A Senate Warning to Mr. Trump
summary: Forty-three Republicans offer good advice on Syria and Afghanistan.. Donald Trump's alleged isolationist takeover of the Republican Party seems to have been greatly exaggerated. The GOP-controlled Senate on Thursday voted 68-23 to warn Mr. Trump against a premature withdrawal of U.S. troops from Syria and Afghanistan, and the sponsor of the effort was no less than Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.

title: Building the Next Great Startup Hub-in Buffalo
summary: Techstars wants to replicate its entrepreneurial hub model across midsize cities in the U.S.. Silicon Valley in Buffalo?

title: PG&E Gets Court OK to Tap $1.5 Billion of Bankruptcy Loan
summary: People and towns hit by wildfires seek official voices in the utility's chapter 11 proceeding. PG&E Corp. on Thursday won approval from a bankruptcy judge to add $1.5 billion in secured debt to liabilities that already top $50 billion.
